Just on your own shares – the investments you have in your own shares and running parallel to the buyback program, I'm just wondering when you actually investing your own shares, I guess you're not using that straight from trading line, you're just coming into the market when you feel there's an opportune moment. Or are you saying basically you won't cancel the CHF5 billion worth of shares that are to be completed in the next, I guess in the next couple of weeks? You won't cancel them next year, that's the first question. Just secondly, just on the BabyNes, you said it's going very well in Switzerland. Just wondering, does that mean you will do a sort of more of an international launch? Should we expect that over the next couple of months and quarters? Thanks.

Okay, Jon, thanks. The shares, yeah, the treasury shares are bought in the normal market, whereas the share buyback is done on the second trading line. Yes, the intention is what we do in share buybacks will be cancelled. So, hope that deals with your first question. I think, BabyNes, we had a very successful launch based on our criteria for the project and maybe as we progress later on in the year we would like to give you an update, Jon.

But right now, the focus is trying to get the launch right in all the dynamics that included in making such – taking such an important innovation to the marketplace. So, we're very focused in getting the Swiss, which is the first market right, and building and using the learning's there to build the program for the other markets.

Okay. Just to come back to this – you investing in your own shares. You know, how should we think about that going forward then? Will you just act opportunistically if you think the share is looking interesting from however you might want to value it and you just come in and buy the stock in every tier of that every half year when you announce? Or which you announce in the stock exchange in the normal way depending if key ratio are hit on the Swiss Stock Exchange regulations?

Yeah. If you – I don't think we will get to a level where we have to make any disclosure. It is an activity we engage in from time to time. But as I said, it's not a priority for us, it's one way of managing the cash flows in the short-term.

Before we did our – before we did our share buybacks, the share buybacks through cancellation, we – I think if I remember well back in 2004, we had only ever announced a treasury share amount annually, not biannually. So, I don't think you can expect to have regular updates on whether we're buying or selling our treasury shares.
Okay. Thanks.
Thank you. Our next question comes from Simon Marshall-Lockyer [Jefferies International Ltd.]. Please go ahead. Your line is now open.

Yes, good morning Roddy, good morning, Jim. Just two questions, one with the machine-based systems, can you just update us on specialty and the (1:44:10) machine and could you give us some indication as to the approaching deadline in respect to the IP losses around perhaps 2012, I think I'm correct in saying?

And the second question is could you give us some more granularity in perspective in Eastern Europe, including Russia, but particularly on Poland, Russia and Ukraine, how this part of the business trended in the first half and what you're expecting there? Thank you.

On specialty, to start specialty has continued to perform very well. It's to our expectations. We're not going to give you any numbers because it's so clearly not material at this stage. The clear focus now, obviously, is to have a very successful Christmas season as with the other systems machines, the big sell-in for the machines is during the Christmas season with gifting. But so far, we're very pleased with how specialty is going.

On what you call the capital 2012 issue, I mean, fundamentally we have a whole series of protections around the Nespresso systems. So, there isn't one issue that's going to be material to us. I've got no update to give you because it's – there is nothing new that happens. It's just a situation that we will have some patents come off of protection in 2012, but all the other patents will continue to be on protection. And there's no material business risk to Nespresso.

Russia is bit of a mixed picture. The – we'll start with the zone, the impulse business, primarily chocolate, which is our big zone business continues to suffer from poor consumer sentiment. The other less impulse, more fundamental businesses like the soluble coffee business, the soup business, are doing very well. If you go – and ice cream is also doing okay. If you go out of the zone into nutrition, the nutrition business is doing terrifically well, double-digit growth now for a number of years and no let up there. Going very well. And also, I mentioned in my presentation pet care also performing very well in Russia.

Ukraine, equally – well Ukraine, especially, performing very well indeed across the business. We've been quite active, as you know, in recent years in acquisitions in Ukraine. We have a super business in Ukraine. We've also recently opened up service – our shared service center for Europe in Ukraine and that business is performing very, very well indeed.
And Poland, where I think we're having reasonable progress in the first half. So, we're quite happy with the markets that you mentioned. Russia continues to improve, albeit, a bit slowly.

The other news in Russia is that we're opening a Nescafé factory imminently, maybe just opened. So, that's a big benefit for us in terms of leveling the playing field, having local manufacturing in Nescafé in Russia. Okay. Any -
Thank you.
Thank you. We have no more questions. I would now like to hand the call over to Mr. Singh.

Well, thank you for your attention this morning, your time and attention. As you've seen, we have delivered a very solid performance in the first half which really gives us the confidence that our strategies are working even in these difficult times as we look at the business and the economic environment in which we operate around the world.

The performance in the first half gives us confidence that we can once again recommit ourselves to achieving the Nestlé model in 2011, which as you know, and this time we reiterate our organic growth at the top end of our 5% to 6% range and an improvement in our margins in constant currencies. Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you for joining us today, ladies and gentlemen. That was the Nestlé -
